title: Data
text:
Overview of the College Scorecard
The data is sourced from the U.S. Department of Education. It includes institution-level data files from the 1996-97 academic year through the 2022-23 academic year, containing aggregate information for each institution.
The dataset was last updated on October 10, 2024 and can be accessed using the following link.

title: Data
text:
Background and Purpose
The College Scorecard was created during the Obama Administration to provide transparent, accessible information to help students and families make informed decisions about higher education. It compiles data on metrics such as net price, graduation rates, student diversity, median graduate debt, salary data, and student loan repayment information.
The goal of this dataset was to create a federal tool that offers comprehensive institutional profiles, synthesizing complex and multi-dimensional aspects of higher education into understandable and standardized metrics.
Article found here.

title: Data
section: Initial Analysis on Flaws and Limitations
text:
Initial Analysis on Flaws and Limitations
Although serving as a centralized federal postsecondary information system, the College Scorecard contains flaws that undermine its overall effectiveness:

Lack of Qualitative Information: The Scorecard focuses primarily on quantitative variables, particularly monetary measures of value. By reducing the measure of an institution’s worth to numerical factors, the Scorecard does not fully encapsulate an institution’s mission or character. This emphasis on financial metrics strips away the nuances of an institution and can lead to an inaccurate portrayal of the college experience.
Institutions Covered: Postsecondary institutions sometimes comprise of separate campuses, including online programs and programs under different names. Each organization chooses which of its separate campuses to report data separately, which may cause complications in accurately comparing institutions with branch locations.
Cohort Definitions Vary for Different Metrics: Measures of institutional performance are sometimesbased on different groups of students and are organized by different event dates. Users should exercise linking different data metrics with caution.
Earnings Data is Limited: Earnings data are estimated for undergraduate Title IV recipients, due to its origination from the NSLDS earnings records. The share of each institution’s student body of Title IV students varies substantially due to state and institutional aid policies. In institutions where this share is low, results may be less representative of the entire student body.

title: Data
text:
Data Cleaning Process

College Scorecard
Cleaned College Scorecard data can be found here.

source("scripts/load_and_clean_data.R")

The original loaded education_cohort_data was 6484 rows x 3305 columns. The cleaned dataset is 527 rows x 47 columns.
The College Scorecard Data Dictionary was used to parse through abbreviated terminology and retain all relevant data values. Columns were renamed to improve readability. Data entries missing key values, including acceptance rate, tuition, racial demographics, median loan amount, percentage receiving loan, median earnings after college, and completion rates, were removed. Data entries with the value “PS”, for privacy suppressed data, were removed for consistency. - All med_loan_# variables, initially in char format, were changed into numeric values. - The Avg_Mean_earning variable was created and added as a separate column, calculated by averaging all average mean earnings from Years 6-10 for each corresponding row.
Technical documentation on the data can be found here.

title: Analysis
text:
Key Questions

I. Do Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) have significantly lower average post-graduation earnings compared to non-HBCUs?












    Welch Two Sample t-test

data:  hbcu_earnings and non_hbcu_earnings
t = -12.99, df = 11.008, p-value = 5.09e-08
alternative hypothesis: true difference in means is not equal to 0
95 percent confidence interval:
 -18530.66 -13161.34
sample estimates:
mean of x mean of y 
 30646.67  46492.66 


The Welch Two Sample t-test results indicate a statistically significant difference in post-graduation earnings between HBCU and non-HBCU graduates (p-value = 5.09e-08). The mean earnings for HBCU graduates ($30,646.67) are significantly lower than those of non-HBCU graduates ($46,492.66). The 95% confidence interval for the difference in means ranges from -18,530.66 to -13,161.34, confirming that HBCU graduates earn considerably less, on average, than their non-HBCU counterparts. This result supports the idea that there exist a significant earnings gap between HBCUs and non-HBCUs.


II. Is There a Significant Difference in Post-Graduation Earnings Between Racial Groups Across U.S. Colleges?










Asian Students: There is a positive correlation between the number of Asian students and average earnings, indicating that colleges with more Asian students tend to have higher average post-graduation earnings.
Black Students: There is a negative correlation between the number of Black students and average earnings, indicating that colleges with more Black students tend to have lower average post-graduation earnings.
White Students: There is a positive correlation between the number of White students and average earnings, indicating that colleges with more White students tend to have higher average post-graduation earnings.
Hispanic Students: There is a positive correlation between number of Hispanic students and average earnings, but the best-fit line is less steep than for their Asian and White counterparts.

These plots highlight the disparity in post-graduation earnings across racial groups, with Asian and White students exhibiting higher earnings, on average, than Black and Hispanic students. Further statistical experimentation and tests would be necessary to draw claims about causality.

title: Analysis
section: Linear Model for Racial Disparity in Post-Graduation Earnings
text:
Linear Model for Racial Disparity in Post-Graduation Earnings


Coefficients, Standard Errors and p-values:


                           Estimate   Std. Error      Pr(>|t|)
(Intercept)           44723.0033897 573.50947741 8.295763e-290
Num_White_Students        0.1675265   0.08495377  4.914026e-02
Num_Black_Students       -0.9476908   0.35300530  7.491702e-03
Num_Hispanic_Students    -0.3944273   0.17099896  2.146745e-02
Num_Asian_Students        2.2823179   0.27884623  2.099718e-15



R-squared:


Multiple R-squared: 0.1393846 


Adjusted R-squared: 0.1327898 



F-statistic and p-value:


F-statistic: 21.13567 on 4 and 522 DF, p-value: 3.612555e-16 



Model Overview:
Every race variable from the education_cohort_data_cleaned dataset is included to build a simple linear regression. It displays the change in median earnings as a function of racial composition change, with no other factors included.


Model Findings:
Num_White_Students: A one White student increase in a school is associated with a $0.168 increase in the expected value of mean post-grad earnings of students, but it is not significant (p = 0.947).
Num_Black_Students: A one Black student increase in a school is associated with a $0.948 decrease in the expected value of mean post-grad earnings of students, and it is significant (p = 0.007).
Num_Asian_Students: A one Asian student increase in a school is associated with a $2.282 increase in the expected value of mean post-grad earnings of students, and it is highly significant (p < 0.001).
Num_Hispanic_Students: A one Hispanic student increase in a school is associated with a $0.394 decrease in the expected value of mean post-grad earnings of students, and it is significant (p = 0.0147).
The adjusted R-square value of 0.1328 shows that approximately 13.28% of the variation in median earnings within schools is explained by the model, indicating the model has only a small portion of explanatory power.
The findings from this regression model show disparity in mean earnings after graduating based on the racial composition of undergraduate students. Specifically, schools with higher percentages of Black students are associated with lower earnings. On the other hand, a higher proportion of Asian students is strongly correlated to higher earnings. However, the low number of adjusted R-square is a sign of omitted variable bias. The model could be improved by adding some control variables. including economic and institutional factors.

title: Analysis
section: Residual Plots for The Initial Model
text:
Residual Plots for The Initial Model










Asian students: The residuals show a tighter cluster around zero at lower percentages of Asian students, but as percentage increases, exhibits increasing variability.
Black students: The residuals are concentrated more closer near zero at lower percentages of Black students, but spread out at higher percentages.
Hispanic students: The residuals are mostly centered around zero at lower percentages of Hispanic students, but show greater variability as the proportion increases.
White students: The residuals display less variability and appear more evenly distributed across the range of percentages compared to other groups.

These residual plots indicate heteroskedasticity, where the variance of residuals is not constant across the predictor variable.

title: Analysis
section: Linear Model of Racial Disparities in Post-Graduation Earnings After Adding a Socioeconomic Factor
text:
Linear Model of Racial Disparities in Post-Graduation Earnings After Adding a Socioeconomic Factor

Model Overview:
Adding variables that correspond to student’s socioeconomic factors may serve reduce the omitted variable bias and therefore, improve the model fit. In this model, the Socioeconomic_Div variable is added.


Coefficients, Standard Errors and p-values:


                           Estimate   Std. Error     Pr(>|t|)
(Intercept)            8291.3762990 2.338776e+03 4.276828e-04
Num_White_Students       -0.5160260 8.194784e-02 6.453139e-10
Num_Black_Students        1.0077657 3.149137e-01 1.457336e-03
Num_Hispanic_Students     0.4133961 1.493422e-01 5.838906e-03
Num_Asian_Students        1.6253378 2.327069e-01 8.759377e-12
Social_Econ_Div       55968.0924256 3.519328e+03 1.040459e-46



R-squared:


Multiple R-squared: 0.4206275 


Adjusted R-squared: 0.4150673 



F-statistic and p-value:


F-statistic: 75.64976 on 5 and 521 DF, p-value: 1.559507e-59 




Model Findings
The small p-value for Social_Econ_Div (1.04e-46) indicates that it is highly statistically significant, suggesting a very strong relationship between socioeconomic diversity and average mean earnings. Its inclusion substantially increases the Multiple R-squared value, from approximately 0.14 to 0.42. This indicates that the model’s ability to explain the variability in average earnings has improved significantly. The increase in R-squared confirms that Social_Econ_Div helps the model explain the data more accurately.
However, adding Social_Econ_Div to the linear regression model significantly changes the results because it is a highly influential variable in the dependent variable Avg_Mean_earning, according to the increasing R-squared. When Social_Econ_Div, which calculates the percent low income students under the Federal Pell Grant, is introduced, it strongly correlates with average post-grad earnings. This new predictor changes the “explanatory responsibility” of the other variables in the model, causing their coefficients to shift significantly.

title: Analysis
text:
Limitations
There is the potential issue of multicollinearity, as evidenced by the significant coefficient shifts after adding the socioeconomic diversity variable Social_Econ_Div. In other words, predictors such as racial composition were “capturing” part of the socioeconomic effect, making it difficult to disentangle their individual contributions. Multicollinearity reduces the reliability of the coefficients, which can lead to unstable interpretations regarding the precise effect of each variable.
Another limitation is the simplicity of the model in its current form. While adding Social_Econ_Div improved the explanatory power (R-squared increased significantly), there are likely additional omitted variables—such as school funding, geographic location, or program types—that could further explain post-graduation earnings disparities. Additionally, this model assumes a linear relationship between predictors and earnings, which might oversimplify more complex, non-linear patterns that exist in the data.
Lastly, this dataset categorizes race in its simplest form: White, Black, Asian, and Hispanic. More nuanced data-such as incorporating ethnicity and smaller racial groups-is necessary in drawing key conclusions about the complex racial dynamics in higher education.

title: First Team Meeting
text:
These are the steps that you will take today to get started on your project. Today, you will just be brainstorming, and then next week, you’ll get started on the main aspects of the project.

Start by introducing yourselves to each other. I also recommend creating a private channel on Microsoft Teams with all your team members. This will be a place that you can communicate and share ideas, code, problems, etc.
Discuss what aspects of the project each of you are more or less excited about. These include

Collecting, cleaning, and munging data ,
Statistical Modeling,
Visualization,
Writing about analyses, and
Managing and reviewing team work.

Based on this, discuss where you feel your strengths and weaknesses might be.
Next, start brainstorming questions you hope to answer as part of this project. This question should in some way be addressing issues around racial disparities. The questions you come up with should be at the level of the question we started with when exploring the HMDA data. (“Are there differences in the ease of securing a loan based on the race of the applicant?”) You’ll revise your questions a lot over the course of the project. Come up with a few questions that your group might be interested in exploring.
Based on these questions, start looking around for data that might help you analyze this. If you are looking at U.S. based data, data.gov is a good source and if you are looking internationally, I recommend checking out the World Bank. Also, try Googling for data. Include “data set” or “dataset” in your query. You might even include “CSV” or some other format. Using “data” by itself in your query often doesn’t work too well. Spend some time searching for data and try to come up with at least three possible data sets. (For your first blog post, you’ll write short proposals about each of them that I’ll give feedback on.)
Come up with a team name. Next week, I’ll provide the Github Classroom assignment that will be where you work on your final project and you’ll have to have your team name finalized by then. Your project will be hosted online at the website with a URL like sussmanbu.github.io/ma4615-fa23-final-project-TEAMNAME.

Next time, you’ll get your final project website set up and write your first blog post.

Setting up the site

add your own along with a short introduction and a link to your Github user page.

Once one person is done with this, each teammate in the group can, in turn, repeat steps 3-7. Before doing so, make sure to pull the changes from teammates before starting to make new changes. (We’ll talk soon about ways to organize your work and resolve conflicts.)


Start your first post

To start your first post first, run remotes::install_github("sussmanbu/quartopost") in your Console.
[[OP]] Run quartopost::quartopost() (or click Addins->Create Quarto Post, or use C-Shift-P, type “Create Quarto” and press enter to run the command).

Now you can start working on your post. You’ll want to render your post to see what it will look like on the site.

Every time you want to make a new post, you can repeat step 2 above.
When you want to publish your progress, follow steps 4-7 from Customize your site.

Finally, make sure to read through everything on this site which has the directions and rubric for the final project.

title: What Does the American Dream Mean in Higher Education?
text: Source: The Wall Street Journal

title: What Does the American Dream Mean in Higher Education?
text:
Introduction
THE AMERICAN DREAM: the shiny ideal that America is the land of opportunity and social mobility, and every person, regardless of their race, gender, and socioeconomic status, has the opportunity to climb the social ladder and succeed with enough hard work and determination. Perpetuating the idea of a colorblind society, perhaps any skew in data - certain racial groups having higher incarceration rates or higher poverty levels - can simply be attributed to just that: they didn’t work hard enough. They were given an opportunity for social mobility and failed to seize it. We must ask ourselves: Can anyone who works hard become successful? Does the American Dream even exist, or was it never real to begin with?

Why is Analyzing Higher Education Data Important?
Analyzing higher education data provides valuable insight into a population of students who have opted to pursue higher education, identifying patterns that inform if there exists a fundamental difference in later income and social mobility and status based upon characteristics such as their race and socioeconomic status. This data can further inform if there perhaps lie varying degrees of difficulty to succeed financially for certain groups over other groups, leading back to the question: Does the American Dream in higher education exist?
Note: “Difficulty” itself is a subjective term, as is determining “working hard” as a quantitative measure. The following analysis does not serve to quantitatively define these terms, but does observe that students pursuing a higher degree have put in a baseline level of hard work to which questions arise over if this serves as a predictor to future income/socioeconomic status level.

title: What Does the American Dream Mean in Higher Education?

title: What Does the American Dream Mean in Higher Education?
text:
Thesis Statement
The Earnings Gap: Analyzing Racial Disparity in Post-Graduation Wages Across U.S. Colleges
Post-Graduation earnings across the U.S. colleges are correlated to student demographic factors, specifically socioeconomic status and race. In particular, students from lower income brackets have lower post-graduation earnings than students from high income brackets (1). Further, Black and Hispanic students have lower post-graduation earnings than their White and Asian counterparts (2).

I. Socioeconomically Diverse Institutions Have Lower Median Earnings

Post Grad Earnings based on the Percent of Students with Pell Grants









Percent Pell Grant and Socioeconomic diversity: Defined in the data set as the share of degree/certificate-seeking undergraduate students who received Pell Grants in a given year. Pell Grants are awarded only to undergraduate students who display financial need, and unlike a loan, it does not have to be repaid. This serves as an important measure of the access an institution provides to low-income students, thereby an indicator of an institution’s socioeconomic diversity. Read more about Pell Grants here.
The bar graph conveys the following idea: Institutions who support more lower-income students, albeit more socioeconomically diverse student bodies, have lower post-graduation earnings. This provides evidence that student affluence level prior to college serves as predictor for post-grad earnings.



II. Institutions with Majority-Minority Student Populations Have Lower Post-Grad Earnings

Average Student Post-Grad Earnings Across U.S. Institutions by Dominant Race Population









Average Earnings After College: Defined in the dataset as the mean earnings for students at each institution, each year starting 6 years after a student enrolls in college, up to 10 years after the student enrolls. Enrollment dates are estimated based on FAFSA self-reporting. This data analysis takes the mean of all mean earnings from 6 to 10 years to provide a centralized value for student earnings from 6-10 years after enrollment at each institution.
The plot supports the following idea: There is a difference in post-grad earnings for schools based on their dominant race student population

Asian: The median post-grad earnings for institutions where Asians are the dominant population appear to be around 60,000. The interquartile range (IQR) spans from approximately 50,000 to 70,000, with a few outliers extending up to 100,000 and below 40,000.
Black: Institutions with a dominant Black population show the lowest median earnings, around 40,000. The IQR is quite narrow, suggesting less variability in earnings, with outliers extending slightly above 60,000 and below 20,000.
Hispanic: Median earnings for Hispanic-dominant institutions are around 50,000. The IQR is moderate, spanning from about 40,000 to 60,000, with fewer extreme outliers compared to other groups.
White Institutions with a dominant White population have a median earnings level similar to Asian-dominant institutions, around 60,000. The IQR is wider, indicating more variability in earnings, with several outliers extending above 100,000.

The data suggests that there are significant disparities in post-graduate earnings based on the dominant race population of institutions. Institutions with dominant Asian or White populations tend to have higher median earnings compared to those with dominant Black or Hispanic populations.

section: Post Grad Earnings Across the US
text:
Post Grad Earnings Across the US
#| '!! shinylive warning !!': |
#|   shinylive does not work in self-contained HTML documents.
#|   Please set `embed-resources: false` in your metadata.
#| standalone: true
#| viewerHeight: 600

# Load required libraries
library(shiny)
library(tidyverse)
library(maps)
library(dplyr)
library(scales)

# Load the U.S. map data
us_map <- map_data("state")

# Correct URL for the dataset
url <- "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/sussmanbu/ma-4615-fa24-final-project-group-3/main/scripts/education_cohort_data_cleaned.rds"

# Load the dataset from the URL
download.file(url, destfile = "education_cohort_data_cleaned.rds", mode = "wb")
education_data <- readRDS("education_cohort_data_cleaned.rds")

# Calculate weighted earnings and population for each race
education_data <- education_data |>
  mutate(
    Weighted_Earn_White = as.numeric(Pop) * as.numeric(Perc_Undergrad_White) * as.numeric(Avg_Mean_earning),
    Weighted_Pop_White  = as.numeric(Pop) * as.numeric(Perc_Undergrad_White),
    
    Weighted_Earn_Black = as.numeric(Pop) * as.numeric(Perc_Undergrad_Black) * as.numeric(Avg_Mean_earning),
    Weighted_Pop_Black  = as.numeric(Pop) * as.numeric(Perc_Undergrad_Black),
    
    Weighted_Earn_Hispanic = as.numeric(Pop) * as.numeric(Perc_Undergrad_Hispanic) * as.numeric(Avg_Mean_earning),
    Weighted_Pop_Hispanic  = as.numeric(Pop) * as.numeric(Perc_Undergrad_Hispanic),
    
    Weighted_Earn_Asian = as.numeric(Pop) * as.numeric(Perc_Undergrad_Asian) * as.numeric(Avg_Mean_earning),
    Weighted_Pop_Asian  = as.numeric(Pop) * as.numeric(Perc_Undergrad_Asian)
  )

# Summarize data by state to calculate weighted average earnings
state_earnings_summary <- education_data |>
  group_by(State) |>
  summarise(
    Avg_Earn_White = sum(Weighted_Earn_White, na.rm = TRUE) / sum(Weighted_Pop_White, na.rm = TRUE),
    Avg_Earn_Black = sum(Weighted_Earn_Black, na.rm = TRUE) / sum(Weighted_Pop_Black, na.rm = TRUE),
    Avg_Earn_Hispanic = sum(Weighted_Earn_Hispanic, na.rm = TRUE) / sum(Weighted_Pop_Hispanic, na.rm = TRUE),
    Avg_Earn_Asian = sum(Weighted_Earn_Asian, na.rm = TRUE) / sum(Weighted_Pop_Asian, na.rm = TRUE),
    region = tolower(state.name[match(State, state.abb)]) # Map state abbreviations to full names
  )

# Calculate global color range for average earnings
global_earning_range <- range(
  c(state_earnings_summary$Avg_Earn_White, state_earnings_summary$Avg_Earn_Black,
    state_earnings_summary$Avg_Earn_Hispanic, state_earnings_summary$Avg_Earn_Asian), na.rm = TRUE
)

# Join summarized data with U.S. map data
earnings_map_data <- left_join(us_map, state_earnings_summary, by = "region")

# UI definition
ui <- fluidPage(
  sidebarLayout(
    sidebarPanel(
      helpText("Select a racial group to view their average post-college earnings across the United States"),
      selectInput(
        "race_variable",
        "Select Racial Group to Display",
        choices = c(
          "White" = "Avg_Earn_White",
          "Black" = "Avg_Earn_Black",
          "Hispanic" = "Avg_Earn_Hispanic",
          "Asian" = "Avg_Earn_Asian"
        ),
        selected = "Avg_Earn_White"
      )
    ),
    mainPanel(
      plotOutput("earningsMap", height = "300px", 
                 hover = hoverOpts("hover_info"), 
                 click = "plot_click"),
      textOutput("click_text")
    )
  )
)

# Server logic
server <- function(input, output, session) {
  
  # Render the map based on user input
  output$earningsMap <- renderPlot({
    race_column <- input$race_variable
    
    ggplot(data = earnings_map_data, 
           aes(x = long, y = lat, group = group, fill = .data[[race_column]])) +
      geom_polygon(color = "white", size = 0.2) +
      coord_fixed(1.3) +
      scale_fill_viridis_c(
        option = "C", 
        na.value = "gray90", 
        limits = global_earning_range, 
        labels = comma,
        name = paste("Avg Earnings:", gsub("Avg_Earn_", "", race_column))
      ) +
      labs(
        #title = "Average Earnings by Race Across States",
        fill = "Earnings ($)"
      ) +
      theme_minimal() +
      theme(
        axis.title = element_blank(),
        axis.text = element_blank(),
        axis.ticks = element_blank()
      )
  })
  
}

# Run the application
shinyApp(ui = ui, server = server)

Logic and Calculations for the Map
The dataset education_cohort_data_cleaned.rds contains:
•   Population Data (Pop): Total number of students at an institution.
•   Racial Composition: Proportion of students from different races, such as:
•   Perc_Undergrad_White
•   Perc_Undergrad_Black
•   Perc_Undergrad_Hispanic
•   Perc_Undergrad_Asian
•   Perc_Two_Or_More_Races
•   Average Earnings (Avg_Mean_earning): The average income for students after graduation of the school
Weighted averages was used to “logic out” the map such that:
Weighted Earnings for Race = {Population} * {Proportion of Race} * {Average Earnings}
Why? The dataset aggregates post-grad student earnings for each college, without specifying individual race metrics. Multiplying the proportion student population of a specified race by the student population, and then multiplying the product by the amount post-grad earnings provides a numeric measurement to how racial groups from different colleges are broadly doing post graduation. It is by no means a representation for how individual students are earning, but provides valuable insight in recognizing patterns and understanding racial dynamics on a high level.
Data was analyzed on the state level:
Average Earnings for Each Race in Each State = Sum of Weighted Earnings for Each Race / Sum of Population

Key Insights

White and Asian students who graduate tend to earn more on average in comparison to Black and Hispanic students who graduate,
Geographically speaking, states in the Northeast and West Coast generally have higher earnings, while the South and parts of the Midwest consistently show lower earnings across all races.

title: What Does the American Dream Mean in Higher Education?
section: Conclusion: Unveiling Disparity in Higher Education Metrics
text:
Conclusion: Unveiling Disparity in Higher Education Metrics
The data depicted in the graphs and map reveal a clear pattern: the mean earnings post-graduation vary significantly by both racial demographics and socioeconomic status. And although it cannot be conclusively drawn that the American Dream imposes a false idealistic reality that hard work can automatically be translated to success for any American irregardless of race and socioeconomic status, it is important to note this discrepancy: certain racial groups and people of lower income brackets have lower mean earnings after enrollment in higher education. Simply “buying into” the American Dream can be a comforting notion, but it can also perpetuate harmful stereotypes that people of lower socioeconomic status deserve it because they simply didn’t work as hard. As we move forward, understanding the interplay between race, affluence, and post-graduation earnings can serve as important tool to tackling racial and socioeconomic divide.
